00009 bool parseArgs(int argc, char* argv[])
00010 {
00011         /* Inital values */
00012         showDebug = 0;
00013         bool playGame = true;
00014 
00015         std::vector<std::string> filenames;
00016         for (int i = 1; i < argc; ++i)
00017         {
00018                 std::string arg = argv[i];
00019                 /* Abbreviated options begin with "-", and full options begin with
00020                  * "--" to conform to standards.
00021                  */
00022                 if ('-' == arg[0])
00023                 {
00024                         /* DEBUG */
00025                         if ("-d" == arg || "--debug" == arg)
00026                         {
00027                                 /* Level of debugging needs to be indicated next */
00028                                 if (i + 1 < argc)
00029                                 {
00030                                         int level = atoi(argv[i + 1]);
00031                                         debugOn(std::cout, level);
00032 
00033                                         /* Forces the for..loop to skip over the next argument */
00034                                         ++i;
00035                                 }
00036                                 else
00037                                 {
00038                                         debugOn(std::cout, WARNING_LEVEL);
00039                                         Monday_out(WARNING_LEVEL, std::cerr, "*WARNING: You must specify a debugging level with the \"%s\" switch.\n", arg.c_str());
00040                                         Monday_out(WARNING_LEVEL, std::cerr, "Assuming level %d.\n", WARNING_LEVEL);
00041                                 }
00042                                 continue;
00043                         }
00044                         else if ("-nd" == arg || "--nodebug" == arg)
00045                         {
00046                                 debugOff(std::cout);
00047                                 continue;
00048                         }
00049 
00050                         else if ("-h" == arg || "--help" == arg)
00051                         {
00052                                 /* Indicate that the user wishes to view the help without
00053                                  * playing the game.
00054                                  */
00055                                 playGame = false;
00056                                 continue;
00057                         }
00058                 }
00059 
00060                 /* If we got here, we didn't recognize the argument.  We can show some
00061                  * sort of "that command doesn't exist..." or show the help() if we
00062                  * want...
00063                  */
00064         }
00065 
00066         /* Indicate that the user will continue and play the game.
00067          */
00068         return playGame;
00069 }
00070 
00071 void help(const std::string &filename)
00072 {
00073         std::cout << "Usage: " << filename << " [-d #|--debug #] [-nd|--nodebug] [-h | --help]\n";
00074         std::cout << "\t-d #, --debug #:  Turns on debugging messages to indicated level.\n";
00075         std::cout << "\t-nd, --nodebug:   (default) Turns off extra non-error messages.\n";
00076         std::cout << "\t-h, --help:       Show this help info.\n";
00077 }

00080 int main(int argc, char *argv[])
00081 {
00082         /* Parse command-line arguments, if there are any */
00083         if (argc > 1)
00084         {
00085                 if (false == parseArgs(argc, argv))
00086                 {
00087                         /* User specified "-h" or "--help", so show usage and exit without
00088                          * running the game.
00089                          */
00090                         help(argv[0]);
00091                         return 0;
00092                 }
00093         }
00094 
00095         Game game;
00096         game.Run();
00097         return 0;
00098 }
